column1: This protein is released by cells in the stomach.

A lack of vitamin B12 may be due to dietary factors, including: - Eating a poorly planned vegetarian diet - Poor diet in infants - Poor nutrition during pregnancy Certain health conditions can make it difficult for your body to absorb enough vitamin B12.

They include: - Chronic alcoholism - Crohn disease, celiac disease, infection with the fish tapeworm, or other problems that make it difficult for your body to digest foods - Pernicious anemia, a type of vitamin B12 anemia that occurs when your body destroys cells that make intrinsic factor - Surgeries that remove certain parts of your stomach or small intestine, such as some weight-loss surgeries - Taking antacids and other heartburn medicines for a long period of time
Symptoms of nerve damage include: - Confusion or change in mental status (dementia) in severe cases - Depression - Loss of balance - Numbness and tingling of hands and feet
The doctor or nurse will perform a physical exam.
Treatment depends on the cause of B12 deficiency anemia.
- Some patients may also need to take vitamin B12 supplements by mouth.
A woman with a low B12 level may have a false positive Pap smear.
Shots of vitamin B12 can prevent anemia after surgeries known to cause vitamin B12 deficiency.
